2396398641.name: Olivier Torna
2396398641.message:
Hello, j'ai réalisé un projet similaire avec un Raspberry Pi et un optocoupleur, qui permet d'obtenir un graph de la puissance instantanée en
V.A et en W, ainsi que le suivi de la conso HC/HP quotidienne

Le tout avec un script PHP/JavaScript, une BDD SQLite et des graphiques Google Chart

http://www.magdiblog.fr/gpi...

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Bonjour,
merci d'avoir partagé votre réalisation, c'est du bon travail. Le montage hardware, sauf erreur de ma part, n'est pas de vous, et c'est celui dont je me suis inspiré mais que j'ai écarté car l'optocoupleur est (marginalement) plus dur à trouver que les composants que j'ai retenus. Bon, et ça m'amusait de faire le redresseur moi même.

Je suis mécontent de ma partie logicielle, notamment parce que j'ai donné une résolution trop faible au RRD trop rapidement (il faudrait garder les données à la minute pendant un an, et non pendant deux jours comme je le fais actuellement). Je vais voir si je peux faire quelques emprunts chez vous !

Attention : votre calcul de puissance active est faux. C'est mieux accumuler les données sur une minute et de faire la moyenne, au lieu de simplement récupérer la valeur instantanée toutes les minutes. Ça ne fait pas une énorme différence, mais quitte à faire des calculs autant les faire précis. :)

children.name: Olivier Torna
children.message:
Le montage n'est effectivement pas de "moi" (il n'y a pas non plus 40 possibilités de le faire...), j'ai d'ailleurs cité ma source d'inspiration dans l'article :)

N'hésitez pas à récupérer/améliorer la partie logicielle que je propose, c'est fait pour ça :)

Pour le calcul de puissance, cela reste effectivement "indicatif" et permet simplement de détecter les pics de consommation (comme expliqué dans l'article)

Bonne continuation à vous

2396398641.name: Bruno
2396398641.message:
"Rigoureusement l’intégrale de la puissance apparente doit nous permettre de retrouver l’indice"

Il me semble que l'indice est l'intégrale de la puissance active, et non apparente.
On paye l'énergie active, la puissance apparente dimensionne l'abonnement et les transfos.

P apparente = p active/ cos(phi) = U.I

L'intégrale de la puissance apparente ne sert pas à grand chose selon moi...

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Vous avez raison : les particuliers (et seulement ceux-ci) paient la puissance efficace, et non la puissance apparente. Donc l'intégrale de la puissance apparente ne sera *pas* égale à l'indice dans le cas d'un particulier (même si elle sera quand même proche dans la mesure où le facteur de puissance doit être proche de 1 dans tous les appareils grands public de puissance non négligeable, par exemple les alimentations d'ordinateur qui sont contraintes d'avoir un PFC en Union Européenne).
Cela renforce d'autant l'intérêt d'avoir directement accès à l'indice du compteur, ce qui n'est pas le cas avec les anciens électromécaniques ou pour le gaz et l'eau.

Mes excuses pour l'imprécision dans l'article, que je viens de mettre à jour.

2403111128.name: Robin Jansen
2403111128.message:
I tried probing with an oscilloscope and did not find any analog audio on the ribbon cable. After a while I found a diagram for the CD module which confirmed the pinout I found before. It has indeed no analog audio.
However Pin 1 is a SPDIF signal, so you could convert an analog audio signal to digital and then connect it to Pin 1 of the CN501 connector.
https://uploads.disquscdn.c...

children.name: Robin Jansen
children.message:
I think we can fool the radio thinking it is playing a CD by enabling PIN 8.
https://uploads.disquscdn.c...

children.name: Francesco Barbieri
children.message:
I was wondering the same! I successfully hooked an spdif input to pin 1 after cutting the trace going to it on the PCB, I then added a two way switch to select between the CD player's digital output and my own, but a CD always needs to be present to fool the stereo into thinking it's playing that. If we can figure out how "CDON" works this whole trick could work a lot more elegantly.

EDIT: I suppose we could connect 3.4V VVDC from pin 70 to pin 68 on IC600 to always enable CDON?

children.name: Robin Jansen
children.message: If you put a resistor between pin 10 and 8 you can get it to think there is a CD inside. It has been a while ago but the problem with me was that I could not put in a cd after or get it out. (or something like that) (if the resistor was permanent of course)

children.name: Francesco Barbieri

2458011860.name: Sebastian H.
2458011860.message:
Very good howto ;-)

Some remarks:
1) given the very small price difference why didn't you go with the default Jeenode wireless module? It costs less than a glas of wine, supports encrypted communication and it works with the RPi (I am running such a configuration).
2) the RPi is fully capable of logging and graphing statistics by itself and needs next to no electricitiy. The EEEPC seems like overkill ... but if it is running anyway, fine ;-)
3) when using the CNY70 as a detector for reflectance you can pulse the LED and given the speed of the last dial, you can measure every x ms instead of all the time. It wont run as long, but long enough to not care about battery life ;-)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
1) The small price difference is a good point, but I felt better about the nRF24L01+. I'm not fully certain why, I think its datasheet looked sexier. Oh, and its module didn't require any soldering to be hooked up to the Pi, unlike the RFM12B.
Going for the default wireless module would certainly have been physically cleaner, though - but honestly the mess is mostly of the R-Pi's side, because after a year I still haven't hooked up everything cleanly. At this point, I'm probably going to be stuck with nRF24L01+.
How did you hook up your RFM12B to your Pi?

2) Yeah, the Pi is capable of doing that, but I have an EeePC for my e-mail setup, that includes a webmail. So there's already a web server and persistent storage there.

3) That's what I have in mind of trying. It turns out I'll need the CNY70 for the water meter, because that one doesn't appear to have a magnet. http://perso.aquilenet.fr/~...

children.name: Sebastian H.
children.message:
I soldered the RFM12B to a broken piece of perfboard and also hooked up a DS18B20 to log the temperature (the connected JeeNodes also have a temperature sensor, some also have birghtness, humidity and pressure sensors). Since the JeeNode protocol has ACKs and encryption it was very convenient to implement.

BUT: i had to port the JeeLib so the Pi would understand the data it receives. If I had to do it again I would probably just use another JeeNode and connect it to the serial port of the RPi and be done with it. Should be more reliable, since the Pi isn't a realtime system and misses packets because of timing issues (I couldn't get interrupts on pin change working, so I am polling a pin to see if the RF12 has something for me).

Have you thought about receiving data directly with the EEEPC and skip the RPi?

P.S.: I mainly chose Jeenodes/RF12 because of this: https://piontecsmumble.word... ... apparently there is an open firmware for an electric thermostat which supports the RFM12b radios, but I haven't tried that yet ;-)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
On the nRF24L01+ transmitters, ACKs don't work reliably (I blame the software driver, but I didn't investigate very deeply). I don't mind, though.
As for receiving directly on the eeePC, it's actually harder than using a Pi, which I needed anyway for the electricity monitoring (my article about it is only in french because what I did pertains strictly to french meters): the eeePC doesn't have a SPI interface.
Honestly, although the whole thing works - 20k gas pulses reported, on supposedly dead batteries - it's fairly brittle, largely on the R-Pi side. /dev/spidev0 simply disappears on more recent kernels, in addition to the nRF24L01+ driver being unstable. I'm a Linux developer so I should get around to fixing that some day. But after work, I get tired of work.

At any rate I'm really happy with the JeeNode, somewhat less so with the R-Pi.

children.name: Sebastian H.
children.message:
True, the PC has no SPI, but it has serial (or USB) and a special JeeNode (JeeLink) or a regular JeeNode with FTDI adapter can be attached to receive the signals ... that's probably how i would do it next time ... mainly to have a more reliable receiver and save some hours programming custom software.

On longevity: the JeeNode guy reported his JeeNode was running for over 3 years on one set of batteries last September (http://jeelabs.org/2013/09/... ... sending data every minute ... 1,4 million times ;-)

2458011860.name: Gecko
2458011860.message:
Comment on "incompentence": You don't need to be incompetent or crazy to use OCR for reading your meter. Older meters (e.g. the one I have from Kromschroeder BK-G4 from 1988) neither has a magnet, nor a mirror reflector. So OCR would be the only possibility to read the meter automatically.
(I just read it manually though).

children.name: sven337
children.message:
BK-G4, the same model number that is on my pictures? I wonder whether it has a magnet... :)
Seriously, I never really understood what BK-G4 meant - is that a definite model number or just a vague reference with dozens of models behind it.
I stand by my comment on incompetence - using OCR would be a crazy project, that would consume a lot of power, be expensive and would be very unlikely to work properly, because of focus, camera quality and varying light levels. Not testing things that can't work within reasonable bounds of time, money, and reliability is one of the dimensions of "competence". It's probably feasible, it's just not feasible by a hobbyist on a time, power and money budget.

children.name: Gecko
children.message:
Yes, same model number, but different year. According to the Kromschröder website only models after 1994 include the magnet as impulse generator. As far as I understood BK-G* series is a meter series for "simple" gas metering application, e.g. for natural gas. There are different sizes for different gas consumption. BK-G2,5 to BK-G6 for normal housholds, G10 to G100 for larger consumers (e.g. companies).
To be really sure that mine does not have a magnet I went in our basement with one of those smartphone apps that plot the magnetic field strength. The newer meters in the basement produce a very good measurable pulse when counting. The older ones (e.g. my 1988 BK-G4) don't.
I guess in 1988 no one thought about devices which automatically read meters, transmit the result wirelessly to a palm sized computer, which in turn sends this into a giant database in "the Internet" :-D.

If I had time, I would try the following: Maybe the different amount of white color for each digit is enough to tell the digits apart. Then a simple (IR) LED, IR phototransistor could be enough. The IR LED could be pulsed with a couple of kHz to prevent problems with ambient light.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
I'm curious: how does pulsing help with ambient light? A couple of kHz will probably require a separate oscillator, I don't think it's possible to achieve that reliably with an Atmega (being somewhat busy with other things), especially taking power into consideration. :(
I agree that you'll probably be able to see *something* with the setup you describe - though it might have to be wired to the ADC and filtered in software to really make sense of which digit just passed. From what I've read, some people who have meters designed with a reflective digit have reliability problems already.

Perhaps you should try to get your meter changed! Claim that it broke (true story, my 3 year old electricity meter broke)... Honestly meter monitoring produces cool graphs, and you can see a few interesting things ("gee, I really had a long shower on that day"), but it's not really a *useful* project. I did it because I wanted to play with low-power wireless electronics, but in terms of changing my behavior this hasn't been a real success.

Currently my focus is on lighting. I've automated the lighting in the bathroom about three months ago with very good results, I'll write about that when I find the energy to - although it's far from a finished project at this point.

children.name: Gecko
children.message:
I would guess the frequency does not have to be very stable, because you use the same signal for modulating the LED as you use to "demodulate" on the receiver side (=photo transistor or diode).

IR remote controls for TVs also use the principle of a 40kHz modulated IR signal.
The pulsing should help because you know exactly which frequency you are looking for and filter away all other frequencies. So called "Lock-in amplifiers" also use this principle ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wik... ). (Its also somewhat similar to superheterodyne radio receivers).

Dont have ATMegas >8 Timer counter modules nowadays? there should be one left to produce a stable-enough PWM to pulse the LED.

I just hope that in my next apartment I'll have a newer meter which has a magnet, I guess I or my landlord would have to pay for changing it.
And until then I maybe find some time to try my idea with the LED&sensor.

Electricity consumption I would find quite interesting for me. For example I always clean my dishes with cold water to save electricity (the kitchen only has a electric water heater, only the bathroom gets hot water from the central heating). But I would like to know how much it would actually cost more if I use the hot water from time to time. You can see a lot from monitoring electricity consumption (google smart meter fingerprinting). So, yeah, its not super useful, but still super interesting field to hack :-)
Sadly also the electricity meter does not have a magnet or reflector. The house is super old, and so are most of the meters.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
I've translated my article about electricity monitoring, with some pictures. http://perso.aquilenet.fr/~...

As for cold water dishwashing, I have some doubts about the chemistry - soaps are much less efficient in cold water, if you end up using more soap the environmental equation becomes harder.

children.name: CA
children.message:
Salut !

Donc, ça marche. J'ai commandé et installé un xCarLink2 pour Toyota "Petit". C'est le connecteur qui est petit (2 rangées de 6 pinoches), regardez bien la photo du connecteur sur le site du vendeur avant d'acheter. Ne pas se tromper: Ne pas acheter celui avec le grand connecteur (et ne pas acheter non plus un modèle pour un autre constructeur). Le modèle de mon autoradio est W58824 (noté en façade). Je l'ai commandé sur Amazon, arrivé en 2 jours.

J'ai démonté l'autoradio existant en suivant les instructions qu'on trouve sur Internet, par ex:
http://www.carstereofaqs.co...
http://www.fitaudio.com/?Vi...
C'est vraiment facile: extraire les 2 joues en plastiques qui sont clipsées, dévisser les 4 vis de l'autoradio, et retirer la façade des molettes pour chauffage/ventilation qui est aussi clipsée. L'autoradio est aussi maintenu en-haut pas le plastique du tableau de bord. Il suffit de le soulever et de relever les 3 languettes. Pour remonter le tout, remettre d'abord la façade de ventilation, puis l'autoradio, puis les 2 joues. J'ai pris mon temps et ai mis moins d'une demi-heure. Attention de ne pas laisser tomber de vis dans le puits sans fond ! :)

J'ai connecté le cordon du xCarLink 2 à la place du connecteur 2×6 pinoches existant (d'où sort un fil jaune), à l'arrière de l'autoradio. Puis j'ai passé le cordon du xCarLink 2 jusque dans la boîte à gants. Pour ouvrir complètement la boîte à gant, il faut savoir que de chaque côté, il y a une butée qui l'empêche de s'ouvrir complètement. Donc, un côté à la fois, il faut presser sur le côté de la boîte à gants avec le pouce pour que la butée passe à côté, et tirer en pliant légèrement la boîte à gants (aucun risque).

Ensuite j'ai quand même fait le test et mis l'autoradio en marche pour être sûr avant de tout remonter. Ça fonctionne bien. Le son est très bon, meilleur que mon émetteur FM sur prise allume-cigare ! On utilise donc les commandes comme s'il s'agissait d'un chargeur de CDs. On a 12 CDs virtuels avec chacun 99 pistes disponibles. Ça, c'est ce que dit le manuel. Il faut créer 12 dossiers à la racine de la carte SD ou de la clé USB, chacun nommé "CD01" à "CD12", avec des pistes dedans. Ma carte SD n'est pas structurée de la sorte, mais a des pistes à la racine, ainsi qu'un dossier "New", et d'autres pistes à l'intérieur. Ça marche pourtant très bien. On a donc les fonctions d'un lecteur CD, avec lecture répétée, aléatoire, navigation par dossier, changement de "CD", sauf que c'est sur mémoire flash. Ça remplace le lecteur CD livré avec la voiture (je ne m'en servais plus depuis belle lurette de toutes façons).

Je n'ai pas commandé la fonctionnalité Bluetooth car elle ne répond pas à mes attentes. C'est en fait un kit mains-libres, mais moi ce que j'aurais voulu c'est connecter un casque Bluetooth avec réduction active de bruit (Bose QuickComfort 35) au xCarLink 2 pour écouter la musique en conduisant sur de longs trajets (sans entendre le bruit du moteur). Cette utilisation n'est pas possible avec le xCarLink 2. Donc pour ce cas de figure, j'utiliserai mon téléphone portable et j'enverrai la musique vers mon casque via Bluetooth.

Autre chose: les noms des pistes peuvent s'afficher, mais seulement si les MP3 tags sont présents sur le fichier MP3, apparemment. Je pense que je vais mettre ce petit appareil dans une chaussette pour limiter les vibrations en roulant (l'électronique ça aime pas les vibrations). J'ai payé le xCarLink 2 sur Amazon €65. Très satisfait de mon achat !

https://uploads.disquscdn.c... https://uploads.disquscdn.c... https://uploads.disquscdn.c... https://uploads.disquscdn.c... https://uploads.disquscdn.c...

Bonsoir,
J'avoue que je n'y avais pas pensé ! En effet c'est une alternative intéressante à un MOSFET, mais je suis un peu inquiet par rapport au courant nécessaire pour le commuter. Le module PIR que je cite ici n'est capable que de quelques milliampères. Je ne suis pas très calé en relais mais je pense que c'est un peu léger et qu'il faut un minimum de 10mA. S'il faut rajouter un transistor, autant mettre directement un MOSFET de puissance... mais j'admets qu'au delà de quelques ampères, la question du relais se pose.

Pour le fade on peut toujours rajouter le condensateur comme je décris. Je compte bien réaliser le montage pour tester, car un signal exponentiel n'est pas la forme idéale (qui devrait être logarithmique) pour obtenir un fade-in linéaire.

children.name: Antonio
children.message:
Merci :)
J'aimerais bien vous demander qu'est que vous en pensez d'une solution alternative très très simple, avant de décider d'engager mes organes pour acheter un système Philips Hue. La solution alternative serait d'intercepter le circuit du lustre avec un trasformateur, pour changer l'alimentation de 220V AC à 12V DC. Ensuite je brancherais à ce transformateur deux phares LED dimmable type http://www.diproclean.com/e... en parallèle avec une branche de circuit contenant un condensateur et une résistance.

Le schéma que j'envisage est celui-ci : https://www.dropbox.com/s/u... , où j'ai représenté les deux phares comme deux résistances R2 (R2 = 29 Ohm d'après les valeurs de puissance absorbé, 5 W, et de tension d'alimentation, 12 V). Or, si c'est correcte de représenter les phares comme résistances, j'impose deux conditions au circuit :

1) Au moment de l'ouverture de l'interrupteur, les deux phares doivent sentir une tension d'au moins 90% de 12 V, pour qu'il ne s'éteignent pas tout de suite. Cela implique que R1 doit être petite par rapport à la résistance équivalente des deux phares. J'ai pris par praticité R1 = 1 Ohm.

2) L'allumage et l'extinction des phares devraient suivre une constante de temps d'environ 2 seconds (je renonce dans ce cas-là à la possibilité d'avoir un allumage franc). Cela me donne une capacité d'environ 0.13 F pour le condensateur.

Or, est-ce que cette solution est viable ou elle comporte des risques majeurs de sécurité ? Si tout est OK, où puis-je acheter les composantes dont j'ai besoin (résistance et condensateur) ? Faudrait-il choisir de préférence une typologie spécifique de condensateur ?

Merci !! Antonio

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Tel que vous avez dessiné votre schéma, C et R1 n'auront aucun effet, et les phares vont s'allumer immédiatement.
En effet, si vous construisez bien un circuit RC pour avoir la tension *aux bornes de C* que vous désirez, ce n'est pas cette tension que voient les phares (tel que vous avez représenté le schéma).

Ce que vous vouliez faire est d'avoir R1 en série avec tout le reste en parallèle : R1 série (C//R2//R3).
Or, si la tension aux bornes de R2 et R3 va bien avoir la forme que vous désirez, le montage ne fonctionnera malheureusement pas, car la pauvre R1 va devoir dissiper une puissance importante, et d'autre part la tension maximale aux bornes de R2 et R3 ne sera pas 12V.
Bref, pas viable, même si ça pourrait marcher avec un mauvais rendement (faites attention : R1 va assez probablement brûler, donc risque de sécurité à gérer correctement).

Les solutions de bonne qualité passent nécessairement par un composant actif (transistor).
Le plus simple à mon sens, et pas spécialement coûteux, c'est de refaire ce que j'ai réalisé dans l'article à propos duquel nous discutons, mais en évitant le "LEDNode" qui coûte cher.
Un Arduino (type Nano ou Pro Mini) qui contrôle un transistor de puissance en PWM pour piloter un éclairage 12V. J'en ai plein l'appartement. Si vous prenez un Arduino en 3.3V (typo pro mini) attention à la tension du seuil du transistor, qui devra impérativement être "logic level". Pour des courants faibles, le FDS6690 me donne satisfaction (c'est un composant monté en surface donc ça demande un peu d'expérience).

children.name: Antonio
children.message:
Merci encore... j'hésite un peu à passer aux composants actifs car je n'ai aucune expérience dans le montage de ce genre de circuits. J'ai essayé donc d'améliorer l'option "passive" (pour avoir aussi un allumage graduel des phares, chose qui à la fin me convient tout à fait) et j'ai effectué une simulation du circuit, disponible ici :

http://www.falstad.com/circ...

Comme vous le remarquiez, les résistances en amont des phares devront dissiper (bien que pour des pics) des puissances importantes, jusqu'à ~70W. À priori, en choisissant des résistances type https://www.amazon.com/Gold... ça devrait marcher, n'est-ce pas ? Par contre, je suis d'accord que ce circuit n'est probablement pas le mieux en terme de rendement :)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Oui je pense que ça devrait marcher (je ne vérifie pas vos calculs).
Cela dit... je pense au contrôleur de LED basé sur un PT4115 dont j'ai parlé dans cet article : https://perso.aquilenet.fr/...

Il a un pin DIM sur lequel vous pouvez appliquer une tension variable. L'idée étant d'utiliser un circuit RC pour contrôler le pin DIM du contrôleur, et le contrôleur fera son travail pour piloter des LED de manière appropriée.
Ça vous permettrait d'utiliser des LED de puissance (par exemple 10W).

children.message:
Sur la photo de la carte, on voit en blanc l'ESP-201 (seule ESP-201 que je possède et je n'en achèterai pas d'autre). À gauche les deux résistances et le jumper servent à configurer l'ESP en mode "flash" ou "exécution".
À droite de l'ESP-201, le composant orange est un fusible automatique (là c'est un modèle 3 ampères, si ma mémoire est bonne, ce qui est une valeur un peu trop forte pour être utile).
En dessous du connecteur d'alim, on voit deux diodes silicium type 1N4004 qui servent à redresser la tension d'alim (qui est du 24V AC). Elles sont en série afin d'abaisser un peu la tension perçue par le module buck (qui n'est pas la référence mentionnée dans l'article, mais qui dans le montage final est ce module : http://www.ebay.com/itm/281... ). Le buck ne tolère que 24V à son entrée donc j'ai jugé intéressant d'avoir 2*0.7V de "voltage drop" avant.
Il y a également une zener dont j'avoue ne pas trop me souvenir de l'utilité, mais vu comme elle est câblée je pense que c'est une zener 3.3V que j'ai mis là pour garantir la stabilité de la sortie. C'est probablement inutile voire nuisible.
Le condensateur sert à stabiliser la tension de sortie. Flasher l'ESP8266 génère des pics de consommation de courant qui posent souvent problème, donc le condensateur est nécessaire.
J'ignore ce que vous appelez "bobine". Si vous voulez parler de celle qui est montée sur la circuit vertical, c'est un des composants du module buck utilisé http://www.ebay.com/itm/281...

children.name: sven337
children.message:
8 channels, 24bit, 48kHz? I don't believe that this will be possible without specialized external chips... and even then...
I'm curious to know what architecture you have in mind?

children.name: colin willcocks
children.message: I have 4 x PCM1803 A/D converters, will use one as master and 3 as slave, into a PIC32 to multiplex the 4 data streams into 256 byte block "ADAT" format (12Mbps), and encode to NRZI (6Mbps), then to the ESP8266 via SPI. I am not sure the ESP8266 SPI is capable of that rate, and may have to look at other WiFi modules. Looking to do lowest latency audio for live use, so fancy data compression methods are not desirable which require too much buffering. The other end will be another ESP8266 with 4 x PCM1770 D/A. The ESP8266 will only be used to push data through end to as quickly as possible, probably using UDP, not sure if stripping unnecessary parts of the TCP/IP stack will help... I am open to suggestions :-)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Unless I'm mistaken your data stream will be 8.79Mbps. NRZI is not a compression scheme, so how do you get down to 6Mbps?
Transmitting 9Mbps from the PIC to the ESP8266 via SPI shouldn't be too hard. I'm not sure if the ESP8266 will be able to push 9Mbps over wifi, however, especially if you use small packets to reduce latency. Think hard about your latency requirements, because it would be best to send ~1.5kB packets instead of 256 bytes.

(It's not terribly useful, but you may want to consider data compression methods at the scale of one audio packet. The delta7 thing I'm describing (which won't apply to you) is simple and provides some benefits. Even a RLE scheme might help. If latency is really sensitive I think you should be able to hide it entirely by doing it on the fly when you acquire data. My code does it at packet send time because it was easier to implement, but it's not required.)

I would advise testing the ESP8266 throughput first, to be sure that it can sustain the kind of transfer rates that you seek. ~1MB/s is in the realm of high bandwidth operation, which I (and the community in general, I believe) have little practical experience with.

Another thing comes to mind, but you're probably more experienced with analog circuitry than I am: the ESP8266 is susceptible to inducing a lot of noise. Don't run your analog circuitry next to the antenna or power wires, and decouple *really* well.

4985328854.name: Jean Taeymans
4985328854.message:
Hi,

Very interesting project, much in line with what I am trying to build, i.e. a device to remote a RF transceiver over a LAN/WAN.
I managed to modify your code to my purpose (8ks/s 16bit sound) in less than a few hours using the Arduino IDE, got a tone streaming on my Ubuntu laptop. The power of the ESP8266 is impressive, it does not give a crimp at 16 packets/s (128kb/s), great for a thing that costs less than 5€.

When I tried to use TCP i.s.o. UDP it didn't work though, apparently the use of the Timer1 (as the interrupt source for the sampling) is incompatible with Arduino's WiFiServer library. I suspect that the Timer1 is used elsewhere for the TCP routines.
Any thoughts about that ? Any other timers available ? Can you please point me to the relevant documentation (the ERSP8266 is the worst documented microprocessor I have ever encountered, the Arduino library is barely better).

All the best and thanks on beforehand.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Hi,
I'm glad my code was useful to someone else. I didn't have a 16bit ADC so I went for 12bit, and raised the sampling frequency to "compensate". Sound quality is good but not great -- for a baby monitor it's quite fine.

I'm not aware of the limitation you are mentioning, but I have 0 previous experience using TCP on the ESP8266. I just don't see the point of TCP for an audio streaming application (unless it's not realtime). It's true that if Timer1 is used for TCP routines, it may interfere with my code. I haven't found evidence that it was used for TCP, but then again I don't know how it's implemented.

You might be able to use Timer0. I'm curious to hear about your results with that.
As for "documentation", what I use are the sources of esp8266-Arduino, some of the Espressif-published documents, their example code with the SDK package, and disassembling the SDK & ROM. As MCUs goes, the ESP8266 is largely undocumented, at least officially. I think they do have a document covering timers and interrupts, though.

children.name: Jean Taeymans
children.message:
Hi again,

Many thanks for your quick response.

I tried "Timer0" i.s.o. "Timer1", but this one gives a "not defined" compilation error (as do "Timer2" or "Timer3"). I am using the same includes as you do. With "Timer1" the sketch compiles and loads, a few seconds after the setup part the following message comes via the serial port:
ets Jan 8 2013,rst cause:4, boot mode:(1,7)
wdt reset
The watchdog seems to be triggered even before any TCP client was available/connected.
The simple telnet example provided with the Arduino ESP8266 IDE compiles and works, adding it to the previous sketch with the UDP streaming (and mutatis mutandi) will make it to crash. Removing the Timer1 setup part will make it work again.

To be honest, the little trials I did so far with UDP were not with a proper ADC, the ESP-01 module I currently use does not have the SPI brough out on the pins. I just synthesized, DDS fashion, a simple square wave instead. For my project I will use the same 12bit ADC as you as it is a fair compromise between price, ease of use and resolution. I have some experience with this component and 65..70dB SNR is quite enough for my purpose. Also I suspect that there are no 16bit ADC on the market with a SPI interface capable say 10ks/s. Most of the audio codecs have a I2S interface, which is alledgedly also available on the ESP8266 but is even less documented.
I grant you that UDP is probably sufficient for sound transfer over a LAN/WAN, nothing can be done with late packets anyhow.
This will however not help me since I need a rather reliable control channel for the RF tranceiver itself. Actually something like telenet at 9600 baud, only a few packets/s bidirectional. I was hoping to combine both functions into the same ESP8266 chip.

Many thanks again and all the best.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
I don't think that timer0 will be usable anyway, but timer1 definitely should work, even with TCP. If you're having issues, something must be wrong in your code elsewhere. Can you share it?
Maybe start from my code and modify it?

You're right that 16bit ADCs that can do 10 or 20ks/s are hard to find (or at least they're not cheap). I2S works on the ESP8266, and you even get DMA, so better performance. It is, however, tricky to use correctly, and the existing projects that make use of it are unfortunately very hard to read (cnlohr I'm looking at you).

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Quoting from the datasheet:
"The MCP3201 device provides a single pseudo-differential input. The IN+ input can range from IN- to VREF
(VREF+ IN-). The IN- input is limited to ±100 mV from the VSS
rail. The IN- input can be used to cancel small signal common-mode noise which is present on both the IN+ and IN- inputs."

So IN- goes to GND.

IP_target_PC was a debugging target (a computer with netcat listening). I used that to get waveforms from the transmitter and analyze them; and to test the compression rates.

Note, the way you've hooked up the LM358P isn't going to work. You need to use it as an inverting amplifier with a bias voltage of Vcc/2 applied to the positive input (I'm writing this from memory). See https://lowvoltage.wordpres... which I followed.

Also what should I do with the udpclient.c and the stats.c and udpserver.c files? Are these for just testing purposes or should they be run individually on the transmitter and the receiver? :(

I hooked up the transmitter and ran the Netcat listening on my laptop to be able to receive any UDP packets being sent by the ESP8266, but seems like the threshold is never reached no matter how loud I talk on the mic and there is no packets sent to the computer IP via the UDP protocol as nothing is displayed on the NC listener. BTW, I am using a 10K resistor across the Pin 2 and Pin 1 of the Op amp for an amplification of 10x

Thanks for the guidance. :)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
It looks like I'm using a 15x amplification on the LM358.
If you have an oscilloscope, look at the signal at the input and output of the LM358 to see if it looks like what you want. It should be centered on Vcc/2 and vary between 0 and Vcc as you speak. If you do *not* have a scope, things are more difficult.

Do you get values on the serial monitor that look like they span a wide enough range? If you don't, then you're probably not listening to the microphone and just looking at noise.

The .c files are for testing on the computer. You can ignore them. The code that runs on the ESP8266 devices is in the xmit/ and recv/ directories.
xmit already implements a "send nothing when below threshold" logic
https://github.com/sven337/...
https://github.com/sven337/...
How it works is covered, briefly, in the article

https://perso.aquilenet.fr/...

Oh, and you can send UDP control packets to the transmitter to alter its behavior. https://github.com/sven337/...
"sendnow" and "threshold" commands are relevant to what you're trying to achieve.

What I would suggest if you do *not* have a scope is to make the transmitter always transmit, then receive the sample locally (you can use my udpserver.c), and open them in audacity as a raw file. It's a bit tricky to get the right parameters for the import, but then you can look at the waveform.

/* Digital filter designed by mkfilter/mkshape/gencode A.J. Fisher

Command line: ./mkfilter -Bu -Hp -o 5 -a 0.012 -l */

// Highpass, Fc=150Hz, 5th order butterworth filter

#define NZEROS 5

#define NPOLES 5

#define GAIN 1.129790960e+00f

static float xv[NZEROS+1], yv[NPOLES+1];

static float filterloop(float input)

{ for (;;)

{ xv[0] = xv[1]; xv[1] = xv[2]; xv[2] = xv[3]; xv[3] = xv[4]; xv[4] = xv[5];

xv[5] = input / GAIN;

yv[0] = yv[1]; yv[1] = yv[2]; yv[2] = yv[3]; yv[3] = yv[4]; yv[4] = yv[5];

yv[5] = (xv[5] - xv[0]) + 5 * (xv[1] - xv[4]) + 10 * (xv[3] - xv[2])

+ ( 0.7834365141f * yv[0]) + ( -4.1083230157f * yv[1])

+ ( 8.6224512099f * yv[2]) + ( -9.0535899276f * yv[3])

+ ( 4.7560230574f * yv[4]);

return yv[5];

}

}

static float xvnotch[NZEROSNOTCH + 1], yvnotch[NPOLESNOTCH + 1];

static inline float filterNotch50Hz(float input);

void loop()

{

xvnotch[0] = xvnotch[1]; xvnotch[1] = xvnotch[2]; xvnotch[2] = xvnotch[3]; xvnotch[3] = xvnotch[4]; xvnotch[4] = xvnotch[5]; xvnotch[5] = xvnotch[6]; xvnotch[6] = xvnotch[7]; xvnotch[7] = xvnotch[8];

xvnotch[8] = input / GAINNOTCH;

yvnotch[0] = yvnotch[1]; yvnotch[1] = yvnotch[2]; yvnotch[2] = yvnotch[3]; yvnotch[3] = yvnotch[4]; yvnotch[4] = yvnotch[5]; yvnotch[5] = yvnotch[6]; yvnotch[6] = yvnotch[7]; yvnotch[7] = yvnotch[8];

yvnotch[8] = (xvnotch[0] + xvnotch[8]) - 2.6983691309 * (xvnotch[1] + xvnotch[7]) + 6.7304484875 * (xvnotch[2] + xvnotch[6])

- 9.3230670449 * (xvnotch[3] + xvnotch[5]) + 11.6679900010 * xvnotch[4]

+ ( -0.7736282195 * yvnotch[0]) + ( 2.1544643168 * yvnotch[1])

+ ( -5.5436864413 * yvnotch[2]) + ( 7.9278080943 * yvnotch[3])

+ (-10.2416524940 * yvnotch[4]) + ( 8.4530545984 * yvnotch[5])

+ ( -6.3025540854 * yvnotch[6]) + ( 2.6118549514 * yvnotch[7]);

// return yvnotch[8];

output = int(yvnotch[8]);

pwmtimer1.setCompare(TIMER_CH1, output); //

int val = analogRead(PA7); // read the ADC value from pin A7 , 0 - 4096, 12 -bit ADC.

lcd.setCursor(0, 0); // set the cursor to column 0, line 0

lcd.print("ADC Val:");

lcd.print(val); //Display ADC value

// delay(500);

}
